description: Its slow, it crashes a lot and its very congused on wether it has updated its signatures or not. But it scan and scans well.

I've used this virus scanner on my Linux systems for a while. To be honest I don't really need it as I use packages from distro repo's for the most part, but the extra on-demand protection is nice.

One thing I notice right off the bat is that the integration with GNOME's CSD is a bit clumsy. There's a "star" icon button on the right of the GtkHeaderBar which seems to open an about page. It would be nice to have more useful things in the header bar e.g. Scan (and then have stuff like "About" in a drop-down hamburger). I say this because scanning for viruses is pretty much the whole point of this application. 

The other UI is also a bit clumsy. Would be nice to have a nicer interface for Clam, but it gets the job done.
bad app, needs a lot of improvements
ClamAv is fine, but ClamTk does everything on the main thread...
summary: Works on the main thread too much

description: Crashed every time I tried to scan a directory.

summary: It does not work, it crashes

description:
It's fairly easy to make a quite polished GTK3 application, this is the worst of them I've ever used. No animations, window resizing does not scale anything, and UI elements clipping in with other UI elements.

That being said, there aren't really any other free (as in free software AND free beer) antiviruses that have a graphical user interface, so this is the best you're getting.

I recommend using the command line ClamAV if you can, but if you absolutely must have a GUI this might work for you.
Have to manually update but hey this is LINUX... Make sure to apply the gnome update for right click treat check.
summary: Installed per Chris Titus for auto virus update - works well
